author: KEITH IDEC
title: Boxing: Gennady Golovkin a mainstream star - Boxing
text:
Gennady Golovkin’s appearance in an Apple Watch commercial that debuted last week was the most significant sign yet that the undefeated middleweight champion has become the rare boxer to make mainstream strides in the areas of marketability and popularity.
Golovkin should provide the next noteworthy piece of proof Saturday night, when a card headlined by the Kazakh knockout artist’s middleweight title unification fight against David Lemieux is expected to sell out Madison Square Garden. Puerto Rican icon Miguel Cotto has been the only boxer to sell out the Garden in recent years, thus there’s no denying now that Golovkin is a star.
The last time Golovkin (33-0, 30 KOs) headlined at the Garden, a crowd of roughly 9,000 attended his three-round demolition of Australia’s Daniel Geale (31-4, 16 KOs) in July 2014.
Montreal’s Lemieux (34-2, 31 KOs), though a 16-1 underdog, is a more appealing opponent than Geale because he, too, is a powerful puncher. That partially explains why more than twice as many fans will attend this card.
It is more the consequence, however, of the likeable, mild-mannered Golovkin becoming a fascinating fighter even casual sports fans want to watch, no matter whom he fights. Ratings for his eight fights broadcast by HBO since September 2012 have steadily increased, as have crowds for his fights in New York and the Los Angeles area. Even such stars as Cotto and recently retired Sergio Martinez have avoided facing Golovkin.
That’s what makes Golovkin’s rise to stardom all the more impressive. He still hasn’t faced a high-profile opponent, yet by methodically destroying B-level boxers or worse, he has developed into a proven attraction.
The Lemieux match also will mark Golovkin’s pay-per-view debut ($59.99 in HD).
Golovkin’s critics claim his perfect record doesn’t mean much, that his aura of invincibility is overrated because he hasn’t beaten star fighters on his way to 20 straight knockouts. His recent reluctance to consider moving up to 168 pounds to face undefeated super middleweight champion Andre Ward (28-0, 15 KOs) also generated negative attention.
Golovkin understandably would prefer to remain at middleweight and fight the winner of the Nov. 21 showdown between Cotto (40-4, 33 KOs) and Mexico’s Canelo Alvarez (45-1-1, 32 KOs).
Whomever Golovkin fights, it’s clear he’ll captivate large audiences. With Floyd Mayweather Jr. retired and Manny Pacquiao approaching retirement, boxing needs as many of those attractions as it can get.
